questions.text: A 35-year-old male sustained a head injury following a motorcycle accident. He experienced a brief loss of consciousness at the scene. Upon regaining consciousness, he developed a severe headache and began to feel drowsy. A CT scan of the head is performed. Which of the following should be the management for this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Option B - Immediate surgical

questions.text: Which of the following is not done in the primary survey of trauma?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - NCCT h

Primary survey

Adjuncts of primary survey
  • Airway maintenance with cervical spine protection
  • Breathing includes ventilation and oxygenation
  • Circulation with hemorrhage control
  • Disability (brief neurological examination)
  • Exposure with environmental control
  • Oxygen
  • Pulse oximetry
  • BP monitoring
  • ECG monitoring
  • NG tube, urinary catheter insertion
  • Ventilation rate
  • ABG levels
  • X-ray- Chest and pelvis
  • FAST

  • ↳ Aspiration

  • ↳ Torticollis
  • ↳ (Option B)
  • ↳ Recurrent laryngeal nerve paralysis (Option D) is a complication typically associated with surgeries or procedures involving the neck or chest, such as thyroid or thoracic surgery. It is not commonly linked to central line placement.

The x-ray reveals a significant amount of air on the left side. What is the most appropriate course of action for treatment?

questions.correct_answer: A. Wide bore needle insertion in the 5th intercostal space

questions.text: A patient sustained a crush injury on their right arm. He was taken to the hospital and on examination, his arm was pulseless, swollen, and dark red. What would be the best way to manage this case?
Which of these is the most life-threatening injury that can be identified by assessing the breathing component of the patient?
questions.explanation:
Immediately life-threatening injuries

Potentially life-threatening injuries
  • Airway obstruction
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Pericardial tamponade
  • Open pneumothorax
  • Massive haemothorax
  • Flail chest
  • Aortic injuries
  • Tracheobronchial injuries
  • Myocardial contusion
  • Rupture of the diaphragm
  • Oesophageal injuries
  • Pulmonary contusion

Tension Pneumothorax

 

Definition

It is a life-threatening condition where air accumulates in the pleural cavity under pressure, causing lung collapse on the affected side, mediastinal shift, and severe impairment of cardiovascular function.

Pathology

• It occurs when air enters the pleural cavity through a "one-way valve" mechanism, leading to lung collapse and mediastinal shift towards the opposite side.

• ↑Pleural pressure→ Opposite lung compression→ ↓venous return→ ↓cardiac output and potentially sudden death.

Aetiology

• Penetrating chest trauma.

• Blunt chest trauma with parenchymal lung injury.

• Iatrogenic lung injury (e.g., central venous catheterisation), and mechanical positive-pressure ventilation.

Clinical Features

• Restlessness, tachypnea, dyspnea, tachycardia, and chest pain.

• Distended neck veins, hyper-resonance, and decreased or absent breath sound on the affected side.

• Late findings may include tracheal deviation and cyanosis.

• Hypotension and severe mediastinal/tracheal shift are also common.

Management

• Needle Thoracocentesis: Immediate decompression with a large-bore needle in the 2nd intercostal space at the midclavicular line, or the "safe triangle". 

• Followed by intercostal chest tube (ICT) placement in the 5th intercostal space in the anterior axillary line.

• Provide oxygen, analgesics, antibiotics, and ventilator support if necessary.

questions.text: Hand rub can be utilised in accordance with the standard hand hygiene protocol in all locations listed below, with the exception of:

options.label: A
options.text: If the hands are visibly soiled

options.label: B

questions.correct_answer: A. If the hands are visibly soiled

questions.text: In the case of a patient arriving at the emergency department with a road traffic accident (RTA), what is the appropriate order of steps in their management? Cervial spine stabilisation Intubation IV cannulation CECT
What does the number (14Fr) marked on the Foley catheter correspond to?
questions.explanation:
Material

LATEX - Less irritation & crust formation

Silicone Coating- for Prolonged use (up to 3 months)

Types
  • 2-way Foley catheter
  • 3-way Foley catheter

Channels

2-way Foley catheter:

  • Main channel: For drainage of urine
  • Small channel: For inflating balloon

3-way Foley catheter:

  • Main channel: for drainage of urine
  • Additional channel for irrigation

Balloon Inflation
  • 20-30 ml saline for self-retaining
  • 30-50 ml of saline for a hemostatic compression effect

Sizes (French scale)

Pediatric patients: 4, 6, 8, 10

Adult patients: 12, 14, 16, 18

Size Calculation

Outer diameter of catheter in mm = Fr/3 (Fr - French units)

E.g., if the size of the catheter is 18 French, then diameter = 18/3 = 6mm

Uses
  • To relieve urinary retention
  • To measure urine output
  • For administration of intravesical chemotherapy
  • 3 ways catheter - for Irrigation after TURP
  • May be used for supra-pubic cystostomy

questions.text: Which of the following statements is accurate concerning split-thickness and full-thickness skin grafts? Primary contractures are more in split skin grafts Secondary contractures are more in split skin grafts Primary contractures are more in full-thickness grafts Secondary contractures are more in full-thickness grafts
questions.explanation:
Feature

Split-Thickness Skin Graft

Full-Thickness Skin Graft

Composition

Epidermis + part of dermis

Epidermis + full thickness of dermis

Graft Size

Large grafts can be taken

Only small grafts can be taken

Graft Survival

Easier

More difficult

Donor Site Healing

Heals spontaneously, allowing repeated grafts

Permanent defect develops, preventing repeated grafts

Graft Contraction (Option A)

Secondary contracture is more significant

Primary contracture is more significant

Common Donor Sites

Inner thigh, upper arm, flexor aspect of forearm, abdominal wall

Upper eyelid, retro auricular skin, supraclavicular skin, antecubital skin, inframammary skin, inguinal skin, genital skin, gluteal skin

Donor Site Exclusions

None

Axilla is not used as a donor site

Advantages of Harvesting

Allows calibration of thickness and large area coverage

Calibration of thickness for small but thick grafts

questions.explanation:
Phases of Damage Control Surgery

Phase

Intervention

Steps

1

Recognition and Decision-making

Intubation, early rewarming, and prompt movement to operation theatre

2

Immediate Laparotomy

Control of bleeding, abdominal packing, and temporary abdominal closure

3

Intensive Care Unit

Ongoing resuscitation and normalisation of physiological and biochemical parameters

4

Re-Exploration

Definitive repair of all injuries

Stages of Damage Control Surgery

Stage

Intervention

1

Patient Selection

2

Control of haemorrhage and contamination (Option A, C ruled out)

3

Resuscitation in ICU (Option B ruled out)

4

Definitive Surgery

5

Abdomen closure

questions.text: A patient presents with multiple stab injuries to the chest. On examination, there is reduced chest movement on the right side and tracheal deviation to the left side. Additionally, the neck veins are distended. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Tension Pneumothorax

It is a life-threatening condition where air accumulates in the pleural cavity under pressure, causing lung collapse on the affected side, mediastinal shift, and severe impairment of cardiovascular function.

Pathology
  • It occurs when air enters the pleural cavity through a "one-way valve" mechanism, leading to lung collapse and mediastinal shift towards the opposite side.
  • ↑Pleural pressure→ Opposite lung compression→ ↓venous return→ ↓cardiac output and potentially sudden death.

Aetiology
  • Penetrating chest trauma.
  • Blunt chest trauma with parenchymal lung injury.
  • Iatrogenic lung injury (e.g., central venous catheterisation) and mechanical positive-pressure ventilation.

Clinical Features
  • Restlessness, tachypnea, dyspnea, tachycardia, and chest pain.
  • Distended neck veins, hyper-resonance, and decreased or absent breath sound on the affected side.
  • Late findings may include tracheal deviation and cyanosis.
  • Hypotension and severe mediastinal/tracheal shift are also common.

Management
  • Needle Thoracocentesis: Immediate decompression with a large-bore needle in the 2nd intercostal space at the midclavicular line, or the "safe triangle".
  • Followed by intercostal chest tube (ICT) placement in the 5th intercostal space in the anterior axillary line.
  • Provide oxygen, analgesics, antibiotics, and ventilator support if necessary.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient undergoes a mastectomy for breast cancer. Post-operatively, the surgeon decides to use a closed suction drain. Which of the following drain types is shown in the image below?
questions.explanation:
Penrose drain (Option A)

This is an open, passive drain consisting of a soft rubber tube. It relies on gravity and capillary action for drainage.

Jackson-pratt drain (Option B)

Consists of a soft, flattened silicone tube connected to a soft plastic bulb

The bulb can be compressed to create negative pressure

Suitable for various surgeries, including breast, plastic, and abdominal procedures

Romovac suction drain (Option C)

Another type of closed suction drain

Uses a spring-loaded mechanism to create constant negative pressure

Often used in orthopedic surgeries and joint replacements

Hemovac drain (Option D)

This is another brand of closed suction drain, similar in principle to the JP drain. However, Hemovac drains typically have a larger, more rigid collection chamber compared to the soft, compressible bulb of the JP

Suture Technique

Description

Knot Used

Interrupted Sutures

Individual stitches, each tied off separately.

Tied like standard knots.

Continuous Sutures

Single length of suture for multiple stitches.

Aberdeen knot at the end. (Option B)

Mattress Sutures

Used to evert or invert wound edges. Tied like interrupted sutures.

Tied like standard knots.

Subcuticular Sutures

Placed under the epidermis for a cosmetic result, using absorbable sutures if needed.

Buried knot.

questions.text: A patient, after a road traffic accident, presented with pain in the abdomen. The resident examined the child and found that vitals were stable, and tenderness was present in the left lumbar region. Which is the best investigation of choice?
The position of the patient in the image shown below is known as:
questions.explanation:
Positioning on the Operating Table

Position

Description

Uses and Complications

Supine Position

Most common position for general surgical procedures.

Modifications of Supine position:

  • Rose’s position
  • Shoulder and Arm Extended
  • Trendelenburg Position
  • Reverse Trendelenburg Position
  • Fowler's Position

General surgeries.

 

Rose's Position

Supine with slight neck extension.

Head and neck surgery.

Shoulder and Arm Extended

Supine with shoulder and arm extended.

Axillary and breast surgery.

Trendelenburg Position

(Option C)

Head end tilted down, knees slightly flexed.

Pelvic procedures, resuscitating patients in shock.

Reverse Trendelenburg Position

The head end tilted upward, placing the head higher than the feet.

Upper abdominal surgeries.

Complication: Right shoulder pain due to CO2 collected under the right dome of the diaphragm during laparoscopic cholecystectomy

 

Fowler's Position

Semi-sitting with the trunk raised at 40° and knees bent.

Neurosurgery, shoulder surgeries, patients with heart or respiratory failure.

Complication: Increased risk of air embolism.

Prone Position

The patient is intubated and log-rolled onto the operating bed with help.

Spinal surgery, extra levator abdominoperineal excision for rectal cancer.

Jackknife Position

(Option B)

(Prone Position Modification)

Chest supported, abdomen relaxed by flexing at the hips.

Provides excellent access to the perineum.

Complication: Positional asphyxia

Lateral Decubitus or Kidney Position

Lower leg flexed, pillow between legs, upper leg flexed in an exaggerated position.

Draining abscesses, lateral thoracotomy, urological and retroperitoneal procedures.

Complication: Increased risk of brachial plexus injury due to hyperextension

Lithotomy Position

Supine with hips and knees flexed, legs in stirrups, hips flexed to 90°.

Gynecological, perineal, and urological procedures.

Complication: Common peroneal nerve injury if legs are not supported properly

Lloyd-Davies Position

(Option A)

(Lithotomy Modification)

Supine with hips minimally flexed (~15°) and a 30° head-down tilt.

Gynecological, perineal, and urological procedures.

Trendelenburg Position

Reverse Trendelenburg Position

Fowler's Position

Prone Position

Jackknife Position

Lateral decubitus or Kidney Position

Lithotomy Position

Lloyd-Davies

questions.text: Match the following 1. Urine Bag 2. Nasogastric Tube 3. Underwater seal bag 4. Suction cannula
questions.explanation:
1. Urine Bag

It is a collection bag attached to a catheter inserted into the urinary bladder to collect and measure urine

2. Nasogastric Tube

It is flexible tube inserted through the nose and down into the stomach for various diagnostic or therapeutic

purposes.

3. Underwater seal bag

A device used in chest drainage systems to maintain a seal and prevent air from entering the pleural space

4. Suction cannula

It is a hollow tube used for the removal of fluid or secretions through suction.

questions.text: The components of qSOFA scoring include: A. Mental status B. Blood pressure C. Respiratory rate D. Heart rate

Match the correct answer related to the nerve injuries in various surgeries: A. Breast surgery 1. External Laryngeal nerve B. Thyroid surgery 2. Hypoglossal nerve C. Submandibular excision 3. Phrenic nerve D. Thymectomy 4. Long Thoracic Nerve
questions.explanation:
A. Breast surgery

4. Long Thoracic Nerve

  • This nerve is commonly injured during breast surgery, leading to a "winged scapula”.
  • Breast surgery can also lead to Thoracodorsal nerve injury.

B. Thyroid surgery

1. External Laryngeal nerve

  • It is a branch of the superior laryngeal nerve and innervates the cricothyroid muscle; it can be injured during thyroidectomy.
  • It leads to hoarseness and difficulty in pitch modulation.

C. Submandibular excision

2. Hypoglossal nerve

  • It supplies motor innervation to the muscles of the tongue.
  • It runs near the submandibular gland and can be injured during its excision, leading to deviation of the tongue towards the affected side.

D. Thymectomy

3. Phrenic nerve

  • The phrenic nerve may be injured during thymectomy, leading to diaphragm paralysis.

questions.text: What could be the most likely reason for a patient presenting with chronic non-pitting edema in the lower extremities?
questions.explanation:
Causes of Primary Lymphedema

Congenital Lymphedema

Lymphedema Praecox

Lymphedema Tarda

  • Age: Seen in < 1 year of age
  • Present at birth.
  • Lower limb, genitalia, and face are involved.
  • Usually, B/L and multiple limbs are involved.
  • Familial version of congenital lymphedema – known as Milroy’s disease.
  • M/C type of primary lymphedema (>90% of cases).
  • Age: 1 to 35 years.
  • M/C seen in females.
  • Usually U/L.
  • Involves calf and foot
  • Familial version of lymphedema praecox - known as Meig's disease.

 
  • Age: Usually seen in > 35 years age group
  • It is a rare disease.

 

Secondary Lymphedema

Filariasis
  • MC overall cause of lymphedema worldwide
  • MC secondary cause of lymphedema
  • Lymphoedema due to Lymphatic obstruction

Surgery
  • Axillary block dissection-
    • MC cause of secondary lymphedema in the USA
    • MC iatrogenic cause of secondary lymphedema
  • Inguinal block dissection
  • Lymphedema due to Lymphatic disruption

Infections
  • Tuberculosis
  • Syphilis
  • Fungal and Bacterial infections

Other causes:
  • Trauma
  • Malignancy
  • Radiotherapy

questions.text: What is the likely reason behind the occurrence of surgical emphysema in the patient following an emergency tracheostomy performed outside of the hospital?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D - Tight sutu

Tracheostomy: Complications

Intraoperative complications
  • Haemorrhage
  • Injury to paratracheal structures, particularly the carotid artery, recurrent laryngeal nerve and oesophagus
  • Damage to the trachea

Early postoperative complications
  • Apnoea caused by a fall in the PCO2
  • Haemorrhage
  • Subcutaneous emphysema, pneumomediastinum and pneumothorax
  • Accidental extubation, anterior displacement of the tube, obstruction of the tube lumen and lip occlusion against the tracheal wall
  • Infection
  • Swallowing dysfunction

Late postoperative complications
  • Difficult decannulation
  • Tracheocutaneous fistula
  • Tracheo-oesophageal fistula, tracheoinnominate artery fistula with severe haemorrhage
  • Tracheal stenosis

Hematoma

Laceration

Capsular tear <1 cm in depth

II

S/C hematoma involving 10-15% surface area

1-3 cm depth

III

S/C hematoma involving >50% surface area

>3 cm or involving Trabecular vessels

IV

>25% devascularization

Laceration involving Hilar vessels

V

Completely shattered spleen

Complete devascularization

questions.text: Identify the condition shown below
questions.explanation:
Port Wine Stain

  • Present at birth
  • Grows along with child and persists
  • Does not regress
  • Most commonly present at face in the areas supplied by 5th cranial nerve (trigeminal nerve)

Strawberry angioma

  • Type of capillary hemangioma
  • Baby is normal at birth
  • Appears at age 1-3 weeks
  • Grows along with child by 1 year of age
  • Complete involuting in 90% cases by 9 years of age
  • Emptying sign is positive

questions.text: Type of necrosis seen in brain is
questions.explanation:
Type of Necrosis

Description

Causes/Examples

Coagulative Necrosis

Preservation of tissue architecture but loss of cellular details

Ischemia, infarction (e.g., myocardial infarction), severe hypoxia

Liquefactive Necrosis

Formation of cystic spaces filled with liquid debris

Brain infarction, abscess formation, pancreatitis

Caseous Necrosis

Cheese-like appearance, granulomatous inflammation

Tuberculosis, fungal infections (e.g., histoplasmosis)

Fat Necrosis

Damage to adipose tissue, release of fatty acids, inflammatory response

Acute pancreatitis, trauma to adipose-rich areas

Fibrinoid Necrosis

Deposition of fibrin-like material in vessel walls, associated with immune-mediated reactions

Vasculitis, malignant hypertension

questions.text: During the surgical procedure for an inguinal hernia in a child, the surgeon observes that the bowel is necrotic . Regarding the resection and anastomosis of the bowel, which statement is accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: The surgeon must use chromic catgut

options.label: B
options.text: The surgeon must not include the submucosa in the sutures

options.label: C
options.text: The surgeon must use the single-layer, extramucosal suture technique

options.label: D
options.text: The surgeon must use the single-layer seromuscular suture technique

questions.correct_answer: C. The surgeon must use the single-layer, extramucosal suture technique
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - The surgeon must use the single-layer, extramucosal suture techniqu

References:

  • ↳ Technique choice depends on bowel condition, location, surgeon preference, and patient factors.
  • ↳ Single-Layer, Extramucosal Suture: Outer bowel layers are sutured, excluding the inner mucosal layer. Reduces leakage risk, especially in necrotic bowel cases.
  • ↳ Double-Layer Technique: Both seromuscular and mucosal layers are sutured separately, offering added reinforcement and widely used in anastomosis.

questions.text: Device shown in the image is used for which purpose?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - Prevent transfusion

Device

Leukoreduction Filter

Purpose

To remove white blood cells from donated blood products

Function

Filters out white blood cells and certain cellular components

Main Application

Enhancing safety of blood transfusions

Benefits

  • Reduces risk of transfusion-related reactions
  • Minimizes febrile non-hemolytic reactions, allergic reactions, and some cases of transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI)

Additional Benefits

  • May reduce risk of viral infections and bacterial/fungal contamination
  • Improves compatibility and reduces adverse immune responses

Usage

  • Used in blood banks and transfusion medicine settings
  • Typically employed for transfusion of red blood cells and platelets
  • May be recommended for specific patient populations at higher risk of complications or prone to transfusion reactions

3

6

Dirty (pus or perforation, or incision through and abscess

7

40
